Attach.definition: to obtain a court order against
Attach.origin: [Anglo-French attacher to lodge (an action in court), seize (a person or property) by legal authority, from Old French atachier to fasten, fix, alteration of estachier , from estache stake]

1.definition: to obtain a court order against (property of another person) that directs an officer of the court (as a sheriff) to seize or take control of the property compare,
1.note: A plaintiff may attach a defendant's property as a way of obtaining jurisdiction for the purpose of bringing a lawsuit or to prevent the defendant from getting rid of property that may be needed to pay a judgment to the plaintiff.

2.definition: to join or make a part of [affidavitsto the suit "Rosalind Resnick"]

3.definition: to create a security interest in (property) and so acquire the right to foreclose on or otherwise deal with property for payment of a debt and to exercise one's rights in the property against third parties see alsoatcompareto become effective

sub_terms.a: to come into existence as a security interest [from the date the interest]
sub_terms.b: to become operative esp. as a right [the right to counselonly at or after the initiation of adversary judicial proceedings ", 467 U.S. 180 (1984)"] see also

3.es: only at or after the initiation of adversary judicial proceedings "
